content.description:
Tips Corner is a bit dirty but a good thin corner that takes gear. A rest roughly halfway up takes out some of the bite. Start the same as

Arching Roof

. Once on the ledge, head up the corner.
content.protection: Bring triples of #0.3-#0.4 and doubles of #0.5.
content.location:
Use the same start as

Arching Roof

.

content.description: Crescent is a bit dirty lower down. An old piton protects the start to where you can mantle up on an obvious ledge. From here, it is big fingers slowly growing in size. Gain a rest and layback the wide section to a hand jam. A few awkward moves gets you to the belay.
content.location:
This route is in the middle of the buttress. The routes start to get spread out the further left you go. Head left after

Arching Roof

for 300 yards. After you pass a knoll, look for light colored rock and the lower ledge.

content.description: Take off up the corner through some tight hands. The crack slowly widens to below the obvious roof. The presence of huecos on the left wall eases your passage as you lay back past the roof. From here, climb big hands to fists. A few awkward moves gets you to the anchors that seem to be too high and too far left but helps with pulling the rope. Be careful of the sharp calcite that lines the crack!
content.location: As you approach the buttress, it is the furthest right route characterized by the sharp looking roof and clean corner.

content.description: This route is the gem of the buttress. The only drawback is the first 15 feet has some crap rock. After that, you get some great rock quality and a full assortment of sizes/moves. After you surmount the brief choss, head up a stair step of tight hands to hands. Move on to a ledge and head up fingers to a #0.75 crack below a small roof. Some difficult jamming gets up to a fist slot that has a small crack in the back. Make a few moves, and gain the anchor.
content.protection: Bring doubles from #0.3-#3 with maybe triples in one or two of the smaller sizes depending if you bother to place in the choss.
content.location:
This is the furthest left route. It is worth the hike. 300 yards left of the

Crescent

, pass several good looking dihedrals until the rock looks like it is about to turn to crap. Right before this, you will see the dark corner that is the route.

content.description:
Though this is in close proximity to

The Warm Up

and shares the last 15', it is well worth doing. It has great movement and involves jamming up sharp rock. As the crack gets smaller, shallow huecos appear where you need them. When the crack peters out, traverse slightly right to finish on the neighboring line.
content.protection: Triples of #0.4, doubles from tellow c3-#0.75. Singles of #3 & #4.
content.location:
The start is four feet left of

The Warm Up

. Begin up the shallow corner and up the splitter face.

content.description: This is a great varied route that starts off with some face climbing to gain a ledge and getting established in the crack on the face. From here, plug and chug up great jams as the crack slowly starts to widen and lean right. Head over the bulge on big hands to some fists as the crack arcs back left to the anchors.
content.protection: Bring singles from #0.3-#0.75; doubles of #1, #2, and #4; and triples of #3.
content.location:
This route is 200 feet left of

The Warm Up

. Look for a corner and a striking splitter up the face.
